results.raw_content:
How Michael Jordan And the Bulls Inspired the World

Luis Miguel Echegaray | Apr 18, 2020

The year is 1992.

Here I am, a Peruvian kid in Lima, a city going through economical and internal conflict but alsoÃ¢Â€Â”and just like the rest of South AmericaÃ¢Â€Â”welcoming the initial effects of modern American culture.

Saved by the Bell is reaching the heights of its popularity ,and even though itÃ¢Â€Â™s been almost year since its release, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II: The Secret of the Ooze is still playing in movie theaters across the capital.

McDonalds were expanding across the city, right next to cevicherias, and everyone wanted G.I. Joe action figures for Navidad.

Thanks to developments in television streaming and market consumption, American products were placing an imprint all over the world, and it was no different in Peru.

We also felt the U.S. takeover in sports. Sure, soccer was still the absolute dominant national force, but thanks to the introduction of international cable, Peruvians were now also watching NBC and ESPN, and their fandom habits were diversifying.

And this is when the NBA entered the party.

If you ask any Peruvian who grew up in the '90s, they will tell you that their memories, in one way or another, always came back to Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls. ItÃ¢Â€Â™s hard to explain this to an American reader, but for South Americans, MJ opened a door that signified more than just basketball. It was as if we realized there was another way you could define an athlete and cultural icon.

So here we are, back in '92. I remember the moment so vividly.

ItÃ¢Â€Â™s May, less than a month away from my 11th birthday, and IÃ¢Â€Â™m staying over at my close friend AlonsoÃ¢Â€Â™s house to watch Game 7 of the Eastern Conference semifinals between the Bulls and my New York Knicks. (I had already made this decision based on my love for John Starks, my favorite player.) ItÃ¢Â€Â™s not official, but I am willing to bet my life savings that Alonso was also the biggest NBA fan in Peru at the time. He was obsessed with the game. Obsessed.

Miguelito Jordan, as my dad called him, and his Bulls returning as the defending champions, are now doing something quite remarkable off the court.Ã‚Â And this was being felt everywhere, even in Peru.

I didnÃ¢Â€Â™t know it at the time, but years later, when I started to work in the sports industry, I realizedÃ‚Â seeingÃ‚Â thatÃ‚Â specific Game 7 (Chicago won 110-81) and watching it with my friend essentially proved to me that sports was more than just a game. It was a cultural movement. And thatÃ¢Â€Â™s what Michael Jordan and the Bulls did for a chubby Peruvian kid in the '90s.

The '90s, you see, was not just a glorious time for the league in America. It was a pivotal moment for the world of sports because Miguelito was rewriting the way weÃ¢Â€Â”the worldÃ¢Â€Â”looked at superstars.

I reached out to Alonso (Guzman) for this piece because I wanted to make sure my memories were more than just nostalgia.

Without a beat, he concurred.

Ã¢Â€ÂœHonestly, at the beginning of 1991, my life changed because I discovered basketball and the Bulls embellished my love for the sport,Ã¢Â€Â says Alonso, now an illustrator and writer in Lima. Ã¢Â€ÂœAnd even though itÃ¢Â€Â™s widely accepted that the Dream Team lifted the game to epic global proportions in Ã¢Â€Â˜92, IÃ¢Â€Â™d actually argue it was the '90s BullsÃ¢Â€Â”alongside satellite TVÃ¢Â€Â”who were responsible for the start of this phenomena. Especially where we grew up.Ã¢Â€Â

For Alonso, his love for Michael Jordan and the Bulls was also personal. Ã¢Â€ÂœWatching them became a means of bonding with my dad,Ã¢Â€Â he says. Ã¢Â€ÂœI remember how he used to talk about their great chemistry, the grace of Scottie Pippen, the strength of Horace Grant and later Dennis Rodman, the clutch play of John Paxson and later Steve Kerr. And as the seasons went by, we became one while watching their games, and even congratulated each other for a good job after every championship clincher. It was as if we were two of 'the guys'. And whenever I watched Phil Jackson on TV, I saw my dad: a throwback grey-haired man who was strict, but also very kind.

Ã¢Â€ÂœThe endless summer days in which I saw more hardwood than sun, all the ups and downs of the seasons (including the '93-'94 team) and that final Bulls salute after Game 6 of the 1998 Finals, when I embraced my dad in the same fashion as Jordan and Phil Jackson. We saw history together, and all those precious moments will remain with me forever.Ã¢Â€Â

After our conversation, he confessed to me that though this team was important to him, he didnÃ¢Â€Â™t realize just how much the Bulls meant until he realized they were a connector, a bridge that united father and son.

The '93-'94 seasonÃ¢Â€Â”as any NBA fan remembersÃ¢Â€Â”came with change like no other for many reasons. The Bulls were without MJ, and due to the fragility of the nation, my family and I left Peru for England.

ItÃ¢Â€Â™s not a surprise to say the culture shock changed me, and life in the United Kingdom transformed almost everything about me. Here I was, no longer a Peruvian, but now also an immigrant, having to acclimate myself to a new world, a new society and a distinctively different way of life.

At first, due to my basic knowledge of English, making friends was difficult. But one of the saving graces were my Air Jordan VII sneakers, my knowledge of U.S. pop culture and, most importantly, Michael Jordan. This immediately became a conversation starter, and slowly, piece by piece, I felt more comfortable in my new home.

Have you ever seen Fresh Off the Boat? That was my lifeÃ¢Â€Â”the Lima-to-London version. I was a foreigner in a new land using pop culture and sports as my Get Out of Jail passes.

Again, just like in Peru, soccer was still the ultimate sport in the country and my first love, but the NBA, Jordan and the Bulls were once again the major influencers in '90s England, especially for young people.

Channel Four in England was the vehicle that introduced U.S. sports to British audiences. In the '80s, the network broadcasted the NFL and achieved success in viewership so the mid '90s was naturally a move for the NBA. Showing the '96-'97 season was a major step for the network. The deal to broadcast the league became the biggest move since making a similar agreement with Serie A soccer, also an incredibly popular league at the time. The show would be called NBA 24/7,Ã‚Â and almost every single British teenager watched it religiously.

The year is now 1998. I am a junior in high school and fully accustomed to English life.  Jordan the Bulls are still iconic and heading to their sixth title. Most importantly, from a personal standpoint, his poster is still hanging on my wall, right next to my other sports hero Dwight Yorke (though his poster would come down the same year after leaving Aston Villa for Manchester United).

In England, the NBA didnÃ¢Â€Â™t just attract the attention of young British fans, but it also represented minorities, especially the black British community. The NBA, therefore, appealed to people of color in England because, as mentioned earlier, it was more than just a sport; it was a symbol of cultural representation.

Ã¢Â€ÂœLike many teenagers growing up in London, a love of the NBA came from watching rap stars on MTV, and all I wanted to do was emulate their style, while rapping into a hairbrush in the mirror,Ã¢Â€Â says James Chinery, now an English teacher and educator in Greater London. He is also a good friend from my college years. Like Alonso, James was influenced by U.S. cultureÃ¢Â€Â”especially Jordan and the Bulls. Ã¢Â€ÂœFirst, it was the Raiders cap and jacket, which were almost like school uniforms growing up in North London. Then quickly, the legend that was Michael Jordan took over the consciousness. Jordan trainers, t-shirts, hoodies, caps, posters on wallsÃ¢Â€Â”you name it, we all wanted it.Ã¢Â€Â

JamesÃ¢Â€Â™s love for MJ and the Bulls elevated after subscribing to Slam Magazine and staying up until midnight to watch theÃ‚Â NBA 24/7 on Channel Four, and his overall view of the world changed because of this team. Ã¢Â€ÂœMy daily cartoon drawings changed from black superheroes to street ball players," he says. "But whatever I drew, they were wearing Jordans and a Bulls cap. To this day, I still religiously wear my AJ3Ã¢Â€Â™S when IÃ¢Â€Â™m not at work.Ã¢Â€Â

My immigrant story is a testament to this very notion: Michael Jordan and the '90s Chicago Bulls offered the worldÃ¢Â€Â”not just AmericaÃ¢Â€Â”a new meaning to sports and superstardom. Their success sparked an international spectacle, idolized and adulated.

And this Peruvian kid will never forget it.Ã‚Â Ã‚

Luis Miguel Echegaray is a reporter, producer and head of Latino/Spanish content with Sports Illustrated. He is also an adjunct professor at CUNY Graduate School of Journalism.

Data coverage: 
Game data: since 1946-47 unless otherwise noted. Regular season: PTS, FG, FT, 3P complete all-time. FTA complete back to 1948-49. FGA, TRB, AST, PF, GS over 99% complete back to 1975-76. MP over 99% complete back to 1976-77. +/- complete back to 1996-97. All other box score stats (3PA, ORB, DRB, STL, BLK, TOV) complete back to 1983-84. Playoffs: PTS, FG, FT, FTA, 3P, 3PA complete all-time. PF complete back to 1948-49. FGA, TRB, AST complete back to 1962-63. GS complete back to 1973-74. MP complete back to 1974-75. +/- complete back to 1996-97. STL, BLK, TOV complete back to 1982-83. ORB, DRB complete back to 1983-84. BPM not available for WNBA & ABA.  
Season data: since 1946-47 unless otherwise noted. All box score stats are covered all-time (though not all stats were tracked for all of NBA history). PER since 1951-52. AST% since 1964-65. TRB% since 1970-71. BPM, VORP, DRtg and Per 100 Poss stats since 1973-74. ORtg since 1977-78. GS since 1981-82. Some stats were available earlier in the ABA. WNBA all-time (since 1997) unless otherwise noted. BPM and VORP not available for WNBA.

results.title: LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Career Scoring Comparison
results.content: By taking a look at their career numbers for points, the first conclusion one can arrive at is that Michael Jordan has better scoring averages both in the regular season and Playoffs while LeBron James scored more total points in both stages. Similar to what happens in the regular season, in the NBA postseason Michael Jordan has a better career point average than LeBron James (+5 points per game) while LeBron James scored more points (+2,175). LeBron James' additional seasons:* LeBron James played 7 seasons more than Michael Jordan in the NBA.In those years â€”his seasons 16 to 22, from 2019 to 2025â€” he averaged 26.6 points in a total of 413 regular season games.

LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Career Scoring Comparison
We break down the scoring legacies of Michael Jordan and LeBron James to determine who has the better numbers. Here you can compare their career totals, points per game, games of 40+ points, 50+, etc. and their year-by-year scoring averages side by side, both in the Regular Season and Playoffs.
Player comparisons:
Career comparison / Season by season / Scoring / Stats
LeBron James and Michael Jordan are among the most prolific scorers in NBA history â€”with LeBron as the all-time leader they combine for an staggering season total of 74,328 pointsâ€” and they also have two of the all-time best scoring averages (with MJ at the top of the list). Here we compare all their scoring stats.
By taking a look at their career numbers for points, the first conclusion one can arrive at is that Michael Jordan has better scoring averages both in the regular season and Playoffs while LeBron James scored more total points in both stages. However, we won't stop there and we'll go into detail to analyze what these statistics are made up of, from how many games they had in each threshold (30+ points, 40+, 50+, etc.) to their season-by-season scoring averages.
On this page we compare:Who has better scoring stats? Career NumbersGames of 30+ points, 40+, 50+, etcShooting StatsPoints Year by Year
Career Numbers
Who has the better scoring stats?

Points in the Regular Season
In his 15 NBA regular seasons played, Michael Jordan averages 3.1 points more than LeBron James in his 22 seasons (30.1 points against 27.0). On the other hand LeBron James scored a total of 9,744 points more than Michael Jordan (42,036 vs. 32,292).
Points Per GameSeasonsLeBron James27.022Michael Jordan30.1+3.115
Total PointsSeasonsLeBron James42,036+9,74422Michael Jordan32,29215

Points in the Playoffs
Similar to what happens in the regular season, in the NBA postseason Michael Jordan has a better career point average than LeBron James (+5 points per game) while LeBron James scored more points (+2,175).

James and his closest friends idolized Michael Jordan while they grew up together in Akron, Ohio. As James grew into a tantalizing basketball prospect capable of jumping from high school to the NBA as the No.Â 1 draft pick, he studied, imitated and drew profound inspiration from Jordanâ€™s tongue-wagging dunks, that fadeaway jumper, his competitive fire â€“ even the little details of the way Jordan wore his sneakers and shorts.â€œM.J. was an inspiration,â€ James told reporters on March 7, 2019, the night he passed Jordan for fourth place on the NBAâ€™s career scoring list. â€œM.J. was the lightning in a bottle for me, because I wanted to be like him.â€Now 38 and just a game or two from passing Kareem Abdul-Jabbar for the top spot on that same list, James is one of the few players who can legitimately be discussed alongside Jordan when it comes to laying claim to the title of G.O.A.T. From the day LeBron James first picked up a basketball, he wanted to be like Mike. James and his closest friends idolized Michael Jordan while they grew up together in Akron, Ohio. As James grew into a tantalizing basketball prospect capable of jumping from high school to the NBA as the No.Â 1 draft pick, he studied, imitated and drew profound inspiration from Jordanâ€™s tongue-wagging dunks, that fadeaway jumper, his competitive fire â€“ even the little details of the way Jordan wore his sneakers and shorts.

â€œM.J. was an inspiration,â€ James told reporters on March 7, 2019, the night he passed Jordan for fourth place on the NBAâ€™s career scoring list. â€œM.J. was the lightning in a bottle for me, because I wanted to be like him.â€

Now 38 and just a game or two from passing Kareem Abdul-Jabbar for the top spot on that same list, James is one of the few players who can legitimately be discussed alongside Jordan when it comes to laying claim to the title of G.O.A.T. (â€œGreatest of All Timeâ€).

No one here is picking sides (and Jamesâ€™ career legacy is still being written), but here is a closer look at how the two superstars stack up today when it comes to the regular season, the postseason and their respective achievements and honors (all stats are through Feb. 5, 2023):

REGULAR-SEASON STATS

Jordan was the flashier scorer â€“ 10 scoring titles and the highest career scoring average in NBA history â€“ and the better defender (leading the league in steals three times), while James has been the better playmaker with 106 career regular-season triple-doubles to Jordanâ€™s 28.

James wins the longevity argument (with anyone), still playing at an All-NBA level and averaging 30 points per game in his 20th season with clear plans to play at least a few more. Weâ€™ll never know where Jordanâ€™s totals would have ended up if not for a pair of early retirements (missing nearly two full seasons when he walked away the first time at age 30).

results.title: LeBron vs. Jordan: Who is the GOAT? Here's how the stats stack up
results.content: Jordan has a relatively large points-per-game lead over James, but James' two extra assists per game ultimatelyÂ led to more points per game for his teams. And even though he's the NBA scoring leader, it's unlikely James will ever eclipseÂ Jordan's scoring average â€“ even thoughtÂ he's beenÂ a 30-pointÂ scorer this season and last. James is the NBA's all-time scoring leader, but Jordan hit major scoring milestones well ahead of James throughout his career. The NBA average has been about 1.2 points per shot attempt throughout the past 40 years â€“ a mark Jordan fell below three times following times away from the game. Jordan only fell belowÂ James' points per season when he broke his foot in his second season and when he returned from each of his retirements.

GRAPHICS
LeBron James
Add Topic
Who is better LeBron or Jordan: After Lakers star broke scoring record, who is really the GOAT?
Jim Sergent Ramon Padilla Mitchell Thorson
USA TODAY

With each passing game, LeBron James, the newly crowned all-time scoring champion,Â puts more distance between himselfÂ and all those enshrined inÂ basketball's hall of fame.
And as he steps onto the court this Sunday in Salt Lake City,Â James will tieÂ Kareem Abdul-JabbarÂ for the most NBA All-Star Game appearances â€“ hisÂ 19th consecutive.
So is he finallyÂ the greatest of all time?
Ask Google:Â "best NBA player of all time." You get 394 millionÂ results in half a second. WhoseÂ picture appears in the top left corner? James. Directly to his right: Michael Jordan.
Settled. Right?
Maybe not. AÂ link just below the photos says: "Here's why Michael Jordan is still the greatest player of all time."
Like any great sports debate, there's a strong argument for either to claim GOAT status. Career averages, games played, championships, honors. We'll walk you through a bunch.
Jordan vs. James: Per game averages
Just consider Jordan's and James'Â averages. TheÂ numbersÂ below would be career games for the majority ofÂ NBA players â€“ not just what you could expect from both of themÂ each time they walked onto the court.
Jordan has a relatively large points-per-game lead over James, but James' two extra assists per game ultimatelyÂ led to more points per game for his teams. And even though he's the NBA scoring leader, it's unlikely James will ever eclipseÂ Jordan's scoring average â€“ even thoughtÂ he's beenÂ a 30-pointÂ scorer this season and last.

Edge: No clear winner
Jordan vs. James: Career points
Yes, there canÂ be some Jordan bias here.
James is the NBA's all-time scoring leader, but Jordan hit major scoring milestones well ahead of James throughout his career. Some may say James has an advantage because scoring has been easier in this era. Yes, 3-pointers play a bigger role in today's game, but the average team scored just over 102 pointsÂ in both of their eras.

Edge: James. Breaking Abdul-Jabbar'sÂ 39-year-old record should mean something.
Games played per season since entering the NBA
"Load management," aka taking games off to recharge, has changed expectations during James' era. He's played all 82 regular season games once in his 20-year career.Â  Jordan played all 82Â in nine of his 15 seasons, includingÂ three consecutive seasons in the Bulls' last three championship seasons.

Edge: Another toss up because their paths and eras are so different. Jordan missedÂ just two regular-season games as he successfully completed two championship runs with a 1992Â Olympic gold medal sandwiched in between. James had a similar run with the Miami Heat and a few more days off. He's also persisted forÂ 20 years as one of the NBA's top performers.
Points per shot attempt
James' and Jordan's shooting efficiencyÂ (total points per shot attempt) crisscrossed early in their careers, but James created some separation from his sixth year on. He topped out at 1.5 points per shot in his final two years with the Heat. The NBA average has been about 1.2 points per shot attempt throughout the past 40 years â€“ a mark Jordan fell below three times following times away from the game.

Edge: James. He's never fallen below the league average after his first season â€“ even as he's drawn most team's top defenders.
Points per season
Jordan only fell belowÂ James' points per season when he broke his foot in his second season and when he returned from each of his retirements. One of those began withÂ a partial season shortly after he gave up his baseball dream with the Birmingham (Alabama) Barons.

Edge: Jordan. In addition to outscoring James in 11 of their first 15 seasons, Jordan holds 10Â scoring titles to James'Â one.
Jordan vs. James: Advanced metrics
Even withÂ advanced metrics which tryÂ to balanceÂ differences in eras, you can make a case for either.
In "value over replacement,"Â the all-encompassing number ofÂ a player's value, James leads everyone who has ever played by a sizable margin. Some of the 30-point difference between him and Jordan canÂ be attributedÂ to his longevity, but grinding through 20 years as one of the NBA's top performers is remarkable.

Edge: James. The two are so close on these and many other metrics, but James' value over replacement easily tips the balance. For what it's worth, only James, Jordan and John Stockton have values over 100.
Jordan vs. James: Honors and awards
Others will argue that the way the game was or is played in any era can't be fully reflected in any set of statistics. The piles of awards and honors that Jordan and James have accumulatedÂ tilt toward Jordan, but both are GOAT-worthy.

Edge: Jordan. He leads in four out of these six categories. Just how many moreÂ awards would Jordan have accumulated if he had not taken a break for baseball or the Bulls had held their core together after their second threepeat?
Jordan vs. James: NBA championships
The GOAT discussion often concludes with who has helped their teamÂ to the most championships.Â With Jordan and James, the comparison is, again, difficult.
Sure, Jordan never lost an NBA championship series in his six trips with the Chicago Bulls. His teams also never played a Game 7.
James, though, brought three organizationsÂ to 10 series (eight consecutive) and won a championship for each team. Of course, it took a second tour with the CavaliersÂ to bring the NBA trophy to his home state.

Edge: Jordan. Two more championships and a more challenging task to build championship teams in Jordan's era â€“ unlike the James era whenÂ he took his talents to Miami andÂ teamed with All-Stars Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh.
Can Team Jordan be converted to Team James?
There'sÂ a lot of data points on either side, but James probably has a few more to make.
Jordan completed his reÌsumeÌÂ in 2009 when he took his place in the Basketball Hall of Fame. At 38, James is two years younger than Jordan was when he retired, and in interviews after JamesÂ broke the scoring record, he sounded as if he still has unfinished business.
Two more championships? As NBA moves into the All-Star break, it appears a fifth championship might be out of his reachÂ this season:Â The Lakers are closer to a play-in spot than a top seed.
40,000 points?Â Even if James' 30-point per game scoring pace slows in the last 23 games of the season, he's on pace to finishÂ the season with more than 39,000 career points. That would likely put him less than a season away fromÂ becoming the NBA's first 40,000-point scorer.
Playing with his son?Â Bronny James, a promising basketball player himself,Â is a high school senior andÂ won't be eligible for the NBA Draft until 2024.Â James wouldÂ be 40 years old just a few months into the 2024-25 season.

results.raw_content:
Michael Jordan vs LeBron James: Comparing NBA Finals Stats of the Two Leading GOAT Candidates

Shubham Singh|PublishedFeb 05, 2024

Michael Jordan and LeBron James. Credits: USA TODAY Sports

NBA enthusiasts love to get into the GOAT debate and it is usually fixated around LeBron James and Michael Jordan. While there are various ways to contrast their contributions, looking at their NBA Finals stats can be a strong methodology. So how did two of the greatest players perform at the highest level of competition?

Advertisement

Jordan is often given the edge when it comes to the Finals because he has a 6-0 record, implying two more titles than LBJ. While James has made four additional trips to the biggest stage, he has lost six times. Therefore, a look at the overall stats for both players can carve out an interesting picture nonetheless.

Michael Jordan

Jordan played in 35 Finals games from 1991-1993 and 1996-1998. In these, he had an incredible 24-11 record and no Finals series featuring Jordan reached seven games. The high-flying athlete won the MVP during all six Finals. He notched 33.6 points, 6 rebounds, 6 assists, and 1.8 steals per game while committing 2.4 turnovers a game. He shot 48.1% from the floor and 80.6% from the free-throw line.

Jordan bagged 1,176 points, 211 rebounds, 209 assists, 62 steals, and 23 blocks in the Finals. Jordanâ€™s best Finals performance was in 1993 against Charles Barkley and the Suns which included a 55-point explosion during Game 4. For the series, he tallied a mind-boggling 41 points, 8.5 rebounds, and 6.3 assists while shooting over 50%.

Jordanâ€™s 41 points per game Finals average remains the top-most in the leagueâ€™s history. His overall average of 33.6 points per game is only second to Rick Barry who put up 36 points per game.

However, one huge difference is that Barry played in 10 finals games, unlike Jordan who did in 25 more games. For his Finals career, Jordan had a plus-minus of 10.9, a PER of 31.5, and a game score of 24.7, which are all extraordinary numbers.

LeBron James

Compared to MJ, James has featured in 55 Finals games thus far. He has a 22-33 record in the finals, meaning that he is yet to touch MJâ€™s Finals total wins despite featuring in four more series. In terms of numbers, James has impressive figures of 28.4 points, 10.2 rebounds, 7.8 assists, and 1.7 steals per game on 48.4% from the floor, 73.1% from the free-throw line, and 35.2% from the three-point line.

So far LBJ has compiled 1562 points, 561 rebounds, 430 assists, 93 steals, and 46 blocks in the final. His 2014-15 Finals can be tabbed as the most impressive performance in terms of numbers. Although he lost the series 2-4 against the Warriors, he put up a herculean 35.8 points, 13.3 rebounds, and 8.8 assists per game including a 44-point effort in Game 1.

But he shot just 39%, so in terms of efficiency, he did take a hit. Apart from that, he has repeatedly shot over 50% during Finals and has gone past the 28 points per game mark in seven out of ten finals series. With 11 triple-doubles, James leads the NBA Finals pack. In terms of minus-plus, James has 9.5, a PER of 29.1, and a Game Score of 23.1.

Michael Jordan vs. Lebron James â€“ NBA Finals statistical comparison.

MJ clears and itâ€™s not really close.

Yet another reason why this media-manufactured GOAT debate really needs to stop. pic.twitter.com/5IqfKDTNxY

â€” The NBA Realist (@nbarealist23) February 5, 2024

Both the GOAT candidates are neck-to-neck in various metrics. While Jordan never lost three games in a Finals series, Jamesâ€™ ability to make the Finals trip consistently is laudable. Therefore, even the NBA Finals comparison will only further divide opinions.

Even then, as per the numbers, MJ seems to be ahead in the race once again, which surely proves his dominance in the league even to this day.

Post Edited By:Hitesh Nigam

About the author

Shubham Singh

Shubham Singh is an NBA Journalist at SportsRush. He found his passion in Writing when he couldn't fulfil his dream of playing professional basketball. Shubham is obsessed with box scores and also loves to keep track of advanced stats and is, particularly, fond of writing CoreSport analytical pieces. In the league, his all time favorites were 80s Bad Boys, Pistons, while Dennis Rodman and his enthralling rebounding made him love the game more. It also made him realize that the game is much more than fancy scoring and playmaking. Shubham is also a huge fan of cricket and loves to watch all forms of women sports.

artifact_id.query: LeBron's all-time scoring and longevity compared to Jordan

results.title: LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Career Scoring Comparison
results.content: By taking a look at their career numbers for points, the first conclusion one can arrive at is that Michael Jordan has better scoring averages both in the regular season and Playoffs while LeBron James scored more total points in both stages. LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan: Career Scoring Comparison
We break down the scoring legacies of Michael Jordan and LeBron James to determine who has the better numbers. Here you can compare their career totals, points per game, games of 40+ points, 50+, etc. and their year-by-year scoring averages side by side, both in the Regular Season and Playoffs.
Player comparisons:
Career comparison / Season by season / Scoring / Stats
LeBron James and Michael Jordan are among the most prolific scorers in NBA history â€”with LeBron as the all-time leader they combine for an staggering season total of 74,328 pointsâ€” and they also have two of the all-time best scoring averages (with MJ at the top of the list). Here we compare all their scoring stats.
By taking a look at their career numbers for points, the first conclusion one can arrive at is that Michael Jordan has better scoring averages both in the regular season and Playoffs while LeBron James scored more total points in both stages. However, we won't stop there and we'll go into detail to analyze what these statistics are made up of, from how many games they had in each threshold (30+ points, 40+, 50+, etc.) to their season-by-season scoring averages.
On this page we compare:Who has better scoring stats? Career NumbersGames of 30+ points, 40+, 50+, etcShooting StatsPoints Year by Year
Career Numbers
Who has the better scoring stats?

Points in the Regular Season
In his 15 NBA regular seasons played, Michael Jordan averages 3.1 points more than LeBron James in his 22 seasons (30.1 points against 27.0). On the other hand LeBron James scored a total of 9,744 points more than Michael Jordan (42,036 vs. 32,292).

Points in the Playoffs
Similar to what happens in the regular season, in the NBA postseason Michael Jordan has a better career point average than LeBron James (+5 points per game) while LeBron James scored more points (+2,175).

LeBron James has played in 1,544 games thus far in his career and earned 58,398 mins in those games. James was named a starter in 1,542 games, and in those matchups he has a rate of 27.0 points per contest and has accrued 41,759 points. He accumulates 25.7 points per 36 mins, in addition to grabbing 7.1 rebounds and earning 7.1 assists so far in his pro basketball career. By putting in 15,331 baskets of 30,263 tries, James has compiled a 50.7% shooting percentage. By burying 2,528 out of his 7,224 baskets from long range, he has accumulated a three-point shooting percentage of 35.0%. By burying 12,803 of 23,039 two-point shot attempts, he has accumulated an average of 55.6%. James has buried 8,569 out of 11,637 shot attempts at the free throw line, which had him earning a clip of 73.6%. Holding an effective field goal rate of 54.8%, he has additionally accumulated 2,757 fouls as well as 5,415 turnovers. Having collected 9,817 defensive boards and 1,775 on the offensive end, James has recorded 11,592 rebounds in total during his NBA career. He has compiled 2,322 steals, in addition to 1,141 rejections and 11,463 assists. In reference to per game stats, James comes in with an average of 7.4 dimes in addition to 7.5 rebounds.
Michael Jordan has earned 41,011 mins and has taken part in 1,072 games in his pro basketball career. Jordan has tallied 32,292 points during his NBA career, sports an average of 30.1 PPG and was named a starter in 1,039 matchups. He distributes 4.9 dimes, grabs 5.9 rebounds and scores 28.3 per 36 mins. Sitting with a shooting percentage of 49.7%, Jordan has buried 12,192 baskets out of his 24,537 attempts. Having racked up 1,778 three point tries thus far in his career, he has recorded a shooting percentage of 32.7% by knocking down 581 of those shots. He has accounted for a 51.0% shooting percentage of by knocking down 11,611 of his 22,759 shots. Jordan has accounted for a 83.5% clip from the free throw line by making 7,327 out of 8,772 attempts. Stepping onto the court with an effective FG percentage of 50.9%, he has also had a total of 2,924 giveaways and has 2,783 infractions. He has tallied 6,672 rebounds in total in his pro basketball career by way of 5,004 defensive and 1,668 offensive. In the matter of sharing the ball, Jordan has a total of 5,633 assists, as well as providing 2,514 steals and 893 blocks. He has an average of 6.2 rebounds in addition to 0.0 assists per contest.

artifact_id.query: LeBron's impact in NBA Finals games and clutch statistics

results.title: Lebron James Finals Stats Cumulative | StatMuse
results.content: LeBron James has averaged 28.4 points, 10.2 rebounds and 7.8 assists in 55 games in the NBA Finals in his career.

results.title: Top 5 clutch moments of LeBron James' NBA career - Sportskeeda
results.content: Despite multiple buzzer-beaters, LeBron James' block in the 2016 NBA Finals remains the most clutch play of his career. As LeBron James moves closer to his 4th NBA Championship, here's a look at 5
results.raw_content:
Top 5 clutch moments of LeBron James' NBA career

LeBron James is on his way to win his 4th NBA championship in 2020. With 4 regular-season MVPs, 3 Finals MVPs, and 3 championships in his career so far, he's already one of the greatest ever to play the sport of basketball.

Kyrie says playing with KD is the first time he's been able to defer late in games ğŸ‘€ (via @boardroom | @boardroompods) pic.twitter.com/qkJG5L9o2y

Despite his illustrious career, King James is sometimes criticized for his performance during clutch moments. Recently, Kyrie Irving, LeBron James' former teammate, took a dig at James and inferred that he (Irving) has never had any teammates in the past who could hit big shots down the stretch.









Top 5 clutch moments of LeBron James' career:

In this article, we'll take a look at 5 of the most clutch playoff moments of LeBron James' career.

Explore the NBA Draft 2024 with our free NBA Mock Draft Simulator & be the GM of your favorite NBA team.

#5. Cleveland Cavaliers vs Chicago Bulls, Eastern Conference Semifinals, Game 4, 2015

This was the first playoffs after LeBron James rejoined the Cleveland Cavaliers in 2014. The Chicago Bulls posed a serious threat to the Cavaliers in the Eastern Conference Semifinals, and took a 2-1 lead in the series.

#TBT to when LeBron James hit a game-winning buzzer-beater over Jimmy Butler and the Bulls in the 2015 Eastern Conference Semis. pic.twitter.com/VurMVnw3oz

In Game 4, with the scores tied at 84-84 and with just 1.5 seconds left on the clock, LeBron James hit a deep 2 from the corner over Jimmy Butler to help Cleveland level the series. The Cavs went on to win the series 4-2 and reached the NBA Finals that year.

#4. Cleveland Cavaliers vs Orlando Magic, Eastern Conference Finals, Game 2, 2009

In 2009, a 24-year-old LeBron James came close to reaching his 2nd NBA Finals. The Cleveland Cavaliers lost the Game 1 against the Dwight Howard-led Orlando Magic in the Eastern Conference Finals.

On this date in 2009, LeBron James hit his 1st playoff buzzer-beater to give the Cleveland Cavaliers a 96-95 win over the Orlando Magic in Game 2 of the '09 Eastern Conf. Finals.Orlando, however, would go on to win the series in 6 games. pic.twitter.com/tOZJzfFLPN

Down 2 points in Game 2 with just 1 second left, the Cavaliers were at the risk of going down 0-2 in the series. LeBron James collected an inbound pass a few feet outside the 3-point line and nailed a high-arcing shot to beat the buzzer.

Though Magic went on to win the series in 6, this buzzer-beater from James remains one of the most memorable moments of his storied career.

Also read: NBA Trade Rumors: The dream starting 5 for the Portland Trail Blazers going into the 2020-21 season

#3. Cleveland Cavaliers vs Indiana Pacers, First Round, Game 5, 2018

In 2018, Victor Oladipo and the Indiana Pacers came closer than ever to upsetting the Cleveland Cavaliers in the first round of the playoffs. In Game 5, with the series tied at 2-2, Oladipo had the ball in his hand with the scores tied at 95.

.@KingJames WINS IT AT THE BUZZER! ğŸš¨ğŸ˜±Pacers vs. Cavaliers, 2018 Eastern Conference 1st Round Game 5 - 2pm ET on NBA TV! pic.twitter.com/88wPXvteqp

What happened next remains as one of the best sequence of plays ever on both ends of the court. LeBron James blocked a layup attempt with 3 seconds left on the clock and drilled a deep 3 to beat the buzzer on the other side. The Cavaliers went on to win the series in 7 games.

#2. Miami Heat vs San Antonio Spurs, NBA Finals, Game 7, 2013

The Miami Heat were one game away from winning back-to-back NBA championships in 2013. In Game 7 of the NBA Finals against the San Antonio Spurs, there was nothing to split the teams up until 3 quarters.

7 years ago today, LeBron did this to the Spurs in Game 7 of the 2013 NBA Finals! 37 PTS5-10 3PT12 REB4 AST2 STLBack-to-back champs! pic.twitter.com/ccoz02gUll

LeBron James took over in the final quarter as he went on to score 16 points in the final 12 minutes. He went 7-11 in the quarter, and also hit a clutch jumper to extend Miami's lead to 4 points with just 28 seconds left on the clock.

#1. Cleveland Cavaliers vs Golden State Warriors, NBA Finals, Game 7, 2016

Cleveland Cavaliers pulled off the impossible in 2016 against the mighty Golden State Warriors. After being down 3-1 in the NBA Finals, the Cavs came back all guns blazing and won the next 3 games to win their first title in franchise history.

LeBronâ€™s block, Kyrieâ€™s dagger, Clevelandâ€™s title. ğŸ†Game 7 of the 2016 Finals was epic. (ğŸ¥: @NBATV) pic.twitter.com/G9owcuKPss

The scores were tied in Game 7 with less than 2 minutes left on the clock. The Warriors' Andre Iguodala was about the give them the lead in what seemed like an easy layup at the rim.

This is when LeBron James made an incredible run from the other side of the court, and leaped as high as anyone could to block the shot off the backboard. To this day, this remains arguably the best block in NBA history.

Amith Sreedhar

Amith is an avid basketball and tennis fan who has been actively associated with Sportskeeda during the 2020 NBA season.

Apart from writing about sports, Amith has attended numerous tennis tournaments and NBA games in the United States and hopes to do it more often in the future.

When not watching decade-old Roger Federer highlights on Youtube, Amith loves traveling and hiking in the mountains

results.title: LeBron James Has Made The Most Clutch Shots In The Last 30 Seconds ...
results.content: LeBron James sometimes gets criticism for not closing games or having a 'killer instinct.' And while the moments may not be as memorable as some other players have enjoyed, the stats show that he is perhaps the most clutch player in the NBA. The playoffs matter more than any other games in the NBA, and making big shots then is what separates the greatest players from the rest. And when it

results.title: Breaking Down LeBron James' Performance in the Clutch by the Numbers
results.content: In the last 30 seconds of a game in which the player's team was tied or behind by three points or fewer, no one in the NBA recorded more assists than LeBron.
results.raw_content:
Breaking Down LeBron James' Performance in the Clutch by the Numbers



Even if his peers don't think so, LeBron James should be synonymous with "clutch" at this point in his NBA career.

Numbers don't lie, and they all support his greatness when the clock is ticking down.

All the playersÂ in the ESPN The MagazineÂ pollÂ who decided they'd rather have Kobe Bryant or Michael Jordan taking the last shot in a close game should do a little bit more digging into those numbersâ€”then submit their votes again. The results would be a little different, even if nearly a quarter of the anonymous, 26-player poll thought that LeBron would go down as the greatest player of all time.

LeBron's battle against the clutch has been the subject of much discussion over the past few yearsâ€”Dan Favale has a great piece on his evolution here at B/Râ€”but there's no more room for debate.Â He thrives when the going gets tough.

Deciding Shots with the Shot Clock Turned Off

Before expanding the definition of "clutch" to include more types of plays, let's first take a look at what happens on shots to either tie or take the lead during the final 24 seconds of either the fourth quarter or an overtime period.

Is there any moment more crucial? The ball is in a player's hands, and he has the opportunity to either ensure victory or defeat. According to Miami Heat beat writer Tim Reynolds, LeBron was pretty darn good in those situations.

Not only did he makeÂ the most shotsâ€”far more than a certain member of the Los Angeles Lakersâ€”but he also shot 41.2 percent from the field. You have to re-contextualize here, as defensive intensity ramps up in these situations. A lower field-goal percentage is to be expected when the game is on the line, and it should be rather telling that only Kevin Durant's mark beat LeBron's.

But these players aren't the only ones who can take game-deciding shots. They can also pass the ball to teammates and have them do the dirty work. It's a concept that not too many superstars are familiar with, as "hero ball" has unfortunately taken over as the method du jour when the contest is on the line.

In the last 30 seconds of a game in which the player's team was tied or behind by three points or fewer, no one in the NBA recorded more assists than LeBron. He, Nicolas Batum and Andre Miller each produced four assists, and LeBron did so while keeping his sheet free from any of those pesky little turnovers.

Paul Pierce was the only other player from Reynolds' tweet to avoid a goose egg in the assist column, and he checked in with two dimes.

The league MVP is already at the forefront of the discussion when isolating scoring, but he pulls ahead by an even wider margin as soon as his elite passing is brought into the conversation. During the 2012-13 season, you wanted the ball in his hands when the game was truly on the line.

But now let's expand the definition of clutch to be much more inclusive, thus raising the sample size enough to draw more conclusions.

Raises Performance During the Final Minutes of Close Games

I wrote a recent articleÂ about why it's so important Dwyane Wade fully cedes the alpha-dog role to his talented teammate, but it's worth bringing up again.

For the purposes of this section, there are going to be two different definitions of clutch. "Clutch 1" will be considered the last five minutes of a game when teams are separated by five points or fewer, and "Clutch 2" will be the last 30 seconds of a one-possession game, regardless of which team was ahead at the time.

If you look at per-36-minute numbers, LeBron has consistently raised his game as the going gets tougher:

Assuming that you could extrapolate his Clutch 2 numbers to a full 36 minutes of action (an admittedly faulty assumption since things change in a one-possession game), LeBron would put up a triple-double while scoringÂ over 60 points. That's pure insanity.

Lebron James' per-36-minute numbers are impressive enough over the course of a contest. But when we enter into Clutch 1 and Clutch 2 situations, he just goes berserk. He scores with reckless abandonâ€”especially when he decides to start attacking the rimâ€”gets everyone involved, and crashes the boards with a fury.

No one else does that to the same extent. And the trend carries over to the postseason as well. In Clutch 1 situations, LeBron averaged 26.5 points, 10.0 rebounds and 11.5 assists per 36 minutes while shooting 44 percent from the field. All of the counting stats are higher than his normal playoff numbers, and the field-goal percentage was only slightly lower.

However, in Clutch 2 situations during last year's postseason, he completely changed his style of play. He met the criteria in six games, and while he didn't record a single rebound or assist, he did manage to average 55.2 points per 36 minutes on 60 percent shooting from the field.

There was just no decline.

Triple-Double and Game-Winner in the Postseason

And speaking of the postseason, how about the fact that LeBron is the onlyÂ player to record both a triple-double and hit a game-winner in the same playoff game, as he did against theÂ Indiana Pacers.

He truly made history when he beat Paul George to the hoop for a relatively easy left-handed layup last Eastern Conference Finals, cementing his legacy as a player who could come up big when the moments got tougher.

Now for the rest of this article, I'm going to be changing the definition of "clutch" once more. Throughout each of the next three sections, it will be defined as the last five minutes of a game when the contest is separated by less than five points, and only players who met those criteria in at least 10 games (while playing two or more minutes per contest) during 2012-13 will be included.

It's a rather broad definition, but, again, it's a necessary one so that we can have at least a fairly substantial sample size.

Across-the-Board Greatness

One of the things that makes LeBron so special is his impact in all major categories during the closing minutes of a game. In fact, no player has as big of an across-the-board impact.

Obviously, it's hard to play a lot of minutes in this type of clutch situation because, by definition, it's just five minutes in any game unless there's an overtime or two. So keep that in mind when you see numbers that are far lower than you might expect.

LeBron didn't score the most points per game in this type of clutch situation, but he wasn't far off the mark.

That wasn't the only area in which he excelled, even if Chris Paul and Kyrie Irving were the only ones in the above graph with higher field-goal percentages. LeBron also crashed the boards quite often during the closing minutes of tight games.

Think we're done yet? Think again. Assists matter too!

LeBron and Rajon Rondo were in a league of their own when it came to passing the ball during the closing stretch of a tight game. They were both willing and able to find openings in the suffocating defenses thrown at them, and the rest of the league just wasn't even close.

Now, how many of the 15 names are repeats? The answer is rather simple: only one.

LeBron appears on all three graphs, and no other player in the NBA finds himself on more than a single top-five leaderboard. He's an elite scorer, rebounder and distributor when the pressure cooker is turned up to its highest notch.

Literally, no one else can say that. And did this change in the postseason? Of course not!

Once the playoffs rolled around, the Heat star finished No. 1 in clutch scoring, No. 4 in rebounding (behind Chandler Parsons, Joakim Noah and Boris Diaw), and No. 7 in assists (trailing Kirk Hinrich, Russell Westbrook, Josh Smith, Manu Ginobili, Mike Conley and Luol Deng).

Still pretty darn elite.

PIE vs. Winning Percentage

Player impact estimate (PIE) hasn't entered the collective consciousness of NBA fans yet, but it's a wonderful tool used by NBA.comÂ to show how involved a player is. Instead of usage rate, which omits assists, rebounds and anything that doesn't finish a play, PIE "measures a player's overall statistical contribution against the total statistics in games they play in."

During clutch situations, no player had a higher PIE than LeBron's 29.7. He was just ultra-involved in the contest at all times, more so than Kobe Bryant (26.5), Kevin Durant (24.3), James Harden (23.3) and everyone else.

But, that's only good if it results in success. Being highly involved can be a bad thing if wins aren't the result.

For that reason, I've put together this graph, which correlates PIE (X-axis) with winning percentage (Y-axis) for the 20 most "involved" players in the NBA:

That's a pretty telling image, as LeBron both had the highest winning percentage and the most involvement. He's the dot in the top right, and he's joined at 80 percent on the Y-axis by his teammate, Chris Bosh.

No one else is close in either category. But now, let's break it down even further and look at his involvement in the Heat's scoring plays.

Involvement in Scoring Plays

Two new stats are relevant here: percent assisted and percent field goals made.

The former represents the number of made shots by teammates that were assisted by the player in question when he was on the court, and the latter shows the percentage of made field goals credited to the player when he was playing.

At this point, it shouldn't surprise you to learn that LeBron James was elite in both categories during crunch time among those who played at least 20 games that met the parameters.

In fact, he finished fifth in percent assisted, behind only Ricky Rubio, Rajon Rondo, Will Bynum and Raymond Felton. As for percent field goals made, he was significantly lower, but still doing pretty well for himself with at 15th.

But let's take this a step beyond and combine the two to show overall involvement in scoring plays, something that I'm just going to call percent scoring. It's calculated rather easily, just by adding percent assisted to percent field goals made.

As you might expect, LeBron is right near the top of the leaderboard:

LeBron and Kobe should stand out to you. The rest are all point guardsâ€”yes, that's Will Bynum benefiting from a small sample size, not Andrew Bynumâ€”which makes sense, because floor generals are naturally more involved in the playmaking.

There's also a major benefit gained from being a superstar on a lackluster team. That's giving Kyrie Irving and Jrue Holiday an artificial boost, as there simply weren't other intriguing options on the Cleveland Cavaliers and Philadelphia 76ers, respectively.

For those reasons, you should be most impressed by LeBron, Kobe and CP3, considering their teammates.

And across the board, you should just be in awe of how great LeBron is with the game on the line. Although there's already a large gap between him and the rest of the league no matter how much time is left on the clock, there's an even larger disparity when nearing the final buzzer in a tight game.

His scoring prowess, willingness to make the right play, and consistent ability to come out on top make him stand out in a big way.

Go aheadâ€”keep denying LeBron's ability to come up big when it counts.Â The rest of us will be over here trying to contain our laughter.

Note: All stats, unless otherwise indicated, come from NBA.com's statistical databases, and all graphics were created with Infogr.am.

Who Faced Tougher And Stronger Competition: Michael Jordan vs. LeBron James


Author:
Flynn Patrick


Publish date:
Mar 7, 2019


LeBron James
Michael Jordan




We are entering the near twilight of LeBronâ€™s career and the comparisons between him and Michael Jordan are going to start becoming more relevant.
There is also a crossroads that has entered the equation for how we view LeBron's legacy though. With other teams clearly ahead of the Lakers in the pursuit of a championship, the clock of father time is in the early stages of ticking on LeBronâ€™s career.
One factor must be considered though when comparing arguably the two greatest players in NBA history:
Who faced better competition?
Yes, Michael Jordan obviously went 6-0 in the Finals and LeBron sits at 3-6. But there are other factors to consider here: if Jordanâ€™s Bulls were in todayâ€™s era instead would they even stand a chance against the Warriors? So letâ€™s take a look at the overall picture, and emphasize 6 hurdles each player had to experience on their way to greatness.
Michael Jordan Competition
1. Larry Bird
When Jordan first entered the league in 1984, Larry Bird was smack dab in his prime. MJ was injured for most of his 2nd season in 1985-1986, but when he returned in time for the playoffs he showed his first signs of greatness against one of the greatest teams in NBA history.
Jordan put up an NBA playoff record 63 points in the Boston Garden in an overtime loss to the Celtics in the 1st round of the playoffs. The Bulls were eventually swept in this series, but this game proved to be the beginning of a path towards greatness.
2. Detroit Pistons
The Bad Boys deserve their own category. The Pistons late 80â€™s success combined with giving Jordan trouble I believe was absolutely crucial in developing Jordanâ€™s killer instinct that would fully blossom in the â€™90s.
Isiah Thomas and Joe Dumars obviously combined for a hall of fame backcourt, but the other players on this team really pushed Jordan in his early career failures. Bill Laimbeer, Rick Mahorn, and future teammate Dennis Rodman helped form a tenacious attitude and identity for this team that became so legendary they even got their own 30 for 30 documentary.
The future path to success was set early for Jordan and this team provided the most difficult obstacle in his basketball career.
3. Magic Johnson
Jordanâ€™s first championship came in 1991, defeating the post showtime Lakers led by Magic Johnson in his last elite season. Johnson won multiple championships in the â€™80s, and the 1991 NBA Finals series in retrospect became a somewhat passing of the torch.
MJâ€™s flair was fully on display for the world to see, including the most iconic layup in history which would be replicated by kids playing in the backyard throughout the decade.
Magic Johnson is a top 10 player of all time and Jordan being able to triumph over him early on his quest to 5 more championships after setting the tone for the â€™90s.
4. Clyde Drexler, Hakeem Olajuwon & Charles Barkley

On his quest for greatness, Michael Jordan won his 2nd championship ring against the Portland Trail Blazers and his 3rd against the Phoenix Suns.
Clyde Drexler if not for Jordan would likely be considered the best SG of the â€™80s and early â€™90s. If Drexler were not on the Blazers in 1984 there is a very good chance Jordan would have been in Portland. Drexler eventually built his resume when he joined forces with Hakeem in Houston while Jordan was on a baseball hiatus and the Rockets won back to back NBA championships in 1994 and 1995.
Charles Barkley remains one of (if not the) greatest players to never win an NBA championship. He came closest in 1992-1993 when he was MVP of the league but he just happened to run into the Jordan train and fell short.
5. Shaquille Oâ€™Neal, Penny Hardaway, Gary Payton & Shawn Kemp

Jordan returned to the Bulls in 1995, and what is now somewhat forgotten is the fact that the Shaq/Penny led Orlando Magic upended the Bulls in the 1995 playoffs. This was the only year in the â€™90s that Jordan lost in the playoffs, and set an early tone for how the rest of Shaqâ€™s career would play out.
Michael Jordan returned to form the next season, with his team posting a 72-10 regular season record. The Mega Bulls ran into Gary Payton and the Seattle Supersonics in the 1996 NBA Finals. Payton, one of the all-time greatest trash talkers in league history, led the Sonics to put up a respectable fight vs. the Bulls only to lose 4-2 in the series.
6. Karl Malone & John Stockton
Michael Jordanâ€™s final 2 championship triumphsâ€™ came against the Utah Jazz in the 1997/1998 NBA Finals. Utah built up one of the most impressive small market teams in league history and the long term chemistry of Malone/Stockton gave these Bulls teams fits.
The Bulls won a ring in 1997 and ultimately Jordan hit the most iconic shot in league history in game 6 of the 1998 Finals, crossing over Byron Russell and sending the Jazz into defeat as Jordan won his 6th NBA ring of the decade.
Read More

Michael Jordanâ€™s 6 Rings Are Better Than Bill Russellâ€™s 11 Rings
Top 10 Best Scorers In NBA History
LeBron James Competition
1. The Spurs

Like MJ, the first section of LeBronâ€™s argument is a team instead of players. I would argue LeBron leading the 2007 Cavs to the NBA Finals at 22 years old is the most impressive feat in NBA history. With his surrounding cast, that team had zero business sniffing a Finals appearance and did.
Ultimately, Tim Duncan and the Spurs proved too much and swept the Cavs 4-0. This taught LeBron an early NBA lesson in the school of hard knocks.
This team would come back to give LeBron fits the next decade as well. The Miami Heat faced off against the Spurs in the 2013 and 2014 NBA Finals going 1-1 against this team, and if not for a miracle Ray Allen 3 point shot they very well could have gone 0-2.
Still, the 2013 victory against a Spurs team with ridiculous chemistry is impressive and helped build the King of Akronâ€™s legacy.
2. Paul Pierce, Kevin Garnett, Ray Allen & Dwight Howard

Over the next couple of seasons to end the 2000â€™s decade LeBron never reached the finals again. Paul Pierce, KG, and Ray Allen joined forces to form a super team and won the 2008 championship. Dwight Howard also was becoming one of the most impressive young centers in NBA history and led the Orlando Magic to the Finals in 2009.
3. Kobe Bryant

One of the biggest what ifâ€™s in NBA history is Kobe and LeBron never meeting in the Finals, but Kobe deserves his own category here. The biggest debate of 2008-2011 was Kobe or LeBron. Kobe was solidifying his greatness on the way to 5 championship rings while LeBron was proving himself to possibly be the most impressive young player in league history.
Kobe showed his mamba mentality that LeBron would carry with him once he went to the Heat.
4. Dwyane Wade, Carmelo Anthony & Chris Bosh

The 2003 draft is arguably the greatest in league history. LBJ entered the league at the same time as these 3 other future hall of famers, and he would join forces with 2 of them in South Beach for an early 2010â€™s dynasty.
Wade won a ring in 2006 as a young player on the Heat, and his championship mentality helped build King James into the player that he is today. Shout out to Chris Bosh as well who is a highly underrated part of that early 2010â€™s Heat run.
5. The Warriors

Mandatory Credit: Kyle Terada-USA TODAY Sports
LeBronâ€™s competition in his 30â€™s can be summarized by one team: The Warriors.
This is a team that likely stopped LeBron from easily being considered the greatest player of all time. LeBron and the newly recharged Cavaliers faced Golden State in the Finals 4 straight seasons, finishing 1-3.
That one win in 2016 was impressive though and arguably the most dominant Finals performance in NBA history. In terms of LeBron and MJ facing competition, this team is the hardest competition either of them faced and there is zero doubt about that.
6. The Future
With LeBronâ€™s career still ongoing, there will be future hurdles for him to navigate through and this debate is not finished.
Still 34 years old and playing at an elite level, King James is still in control of his destiny and it remains to be seen whether the Warriors dynasty will last through the remainder of his career.
Will Anthony Davis join forces with LeBron to become instant contenders? Will Kawhi move back to the states and sign with the Lakers in 2019 free agency?
A lot could happen and itâ€™ll be interesting to see what type of competition LeBron will have to face the rest of his career.

Data coverage: 
Game data: since 1946-47 unless otherwise noted. Regular season: PTS, FG, FT, 3P complete all-time. FTA complete back to 1948-49. FGA, TRB, AST, PF, GS over 99% complete back to 1975-76. MP over 99% complete back to 1976-77. +/- complete back to 1996-97. All other box score stats (3PA, ORB, DRB, STL, BLK, TOV) complete back to 1983-84. Playoffs: PTS, FG, FT, FTA, 3P, 3PA complete all-time. PF complete back to 1948-49. FGA, TRB, AST complete back to 1962-63. GS complete back to 1973-74. MP complete back to 1974-75. +/- complete back to 1996-97. STL, BLK, TOV complete back to 1982-83. ORB, DRB complete back to 1983-84. BPM not available for WNBA & ABA.  
Season data: since 1946-47 unless otherwise noted. All box score stats are covered all-time (though not all stats were tracked for all of NBA history). PER since 1951-52. AST% since 1964-65. TRB% since 1970-71. BPM, VORP, DRtg and Per 100 Poss stats since 1973-74. ORtg since 1977-78. GS since 1981-82. Some stats were available earlier in the ABA. WNBA all-time (since 1997) unless otherwise noted. BPM and VORP not available for WNBA.

LeBron vs. Jordan: A Data-Driven Deep Dive into NBA Greatness

Henry Chukwunwike Morgan-Dibie

Follow

The basketball world has long debated: Whoâ€™s the GOAT â€” Michael Jordan or LeBron James? Today, weâ€™re settling in with the stats to see what the numbers reveal about these two legends.

Dataset Overview

Data Source

1. LeBronâ€™s Career Dataset (lebron_career.csv)

This dataset contains detailed information about LeBron Jamesâ€™ career in the NBA, including game statistics and outcomes. The dataset consists of 1,265 rows and 26 columns. Key columns include:

2. LeBronâ€™s Playoffs Dataset (lebron_playoffs.csv)

This dataset provides detailed statistics for LeBron Jamesâ€™ playoff games. It includes 260 rows and 27 columns, with similar attributes to the career dataset, along with additional playoff-specific columns:

3. Jordanâ€™s Career Dataset (jordan_career.csv)

This dataset contains detailed statistics of Michael Jordanâ€™s NBA career, similar to LeBronâ€™s career dataset. It consists of 1,072 rows and 26 columns, with key columns including:

4. Jordanâ€™s Playoffs Dataset (jordan_playoffs.csv)

This dataset provides detailed statistics for Michael Jordanâ€™s playoff games, including 179 rows and 27 columns. It includes similar columns to the career dataset with additional playoff-specific information:

Each dataset provides a comprehensive overview of the playersâ€™ performances, including basic game metrics (minutes played, field goals, points, etc.) and advanced metrics (game score, plus/minus). These datasets will be used to compare LeBron James and Michael Jordanâ€™s performances across their careers and playoff appearances.

Career Longevity and Total Impact

LeBron James stands out in career totals:

Jordanâ€™s career totals:

LeBronâ€™s higher totals showcase his exceptional longevity and consistent impact across multiple teams and eras of the NBA. His ability to maintain elite performance over a more extended period is truly remarkable.

Per-Game Brilliance

Jordan takes the lead in per-game averages:

LeBron edges out in:

Jordanâ€™s higher scoring average and steal rate suggest a more intense, game-changing presence on both ends of the court during his prime years. LeBronâ€™s numbers reflect a more versatile skill set, focused on overall team impact and facilitating play.

Scoring Machines: A Closer Look

The distribution of points scored per game reveals fascinating insights:

This data suggests that while LeBron is an incredibly consistent scorer, Jordan had a higher capacity for explosive scoring nights, cementing his reputation as one of the most potent offensive forces in NBA history.

Winning Ways

The win percentage trends tell a compelling story:

Jordanâ€™s peak aligns with a dominant team era, while LeBronâ€™s adaptability across different teams is evident in his late-career success.

Peak Performance and Playoff Prowess

Their playoff win percentages are remarkably close:

These numbers indicate that both players were at their most dominant in their late 20s, with LeBron maintaining his peak slightly longer. Their nearly identical playoff win percentages speak to their comparable levels of postseason success and clutch performance.

Key Takeaways

In conclusion, the numbers paint a picture of two distinct but equally impactful styles of greatness. Jordanâ€™s career is characterized by unmatched scoring prowess and a period of absolute dominance, while LeBronâ€™s showcases incredible longevity, versatility, and the ability to transform multiple franchises into contenders.

In the end, this data doesnâ€™t definitively settle the GOAT debate â€” but it does deepen our appreciation for the unique strengths each player brought to the game. Itâ€™s a reminder that greatness in basketball can take different forms, and that weâ€™re fortunate to have witnessed two of the gameâ€™s most extraordinary talents.

Whatâ€™s your take on these stats? Do they sway your opinion in the Jordan vs. LeBron debate? Share your thoughts in the comments below!

Michael Jordan vs LeBron James: A career analysis
An in depth analysis of the careers of both of the commonly recognized G.O.A.T.S.

Rishon Ghosh, Staff Writer
September 26, 2024

I. Introduction
The debate of who is basketballâ€™s GOAT has been ongoing for years, with fans and analysts comparing the two playersâ€™ skills, achievements, and impact on the game. Both Jordan and James have left a lasting legacy in the NBA, making it a difficult decision for many to determine who is the greatest of all time. While Jordan is often praised for his six championships and unbeatable competitive spirit, James has also garnered respect for his versatility and longevity in the league. Ultimately, the GOAT debate may never have a definitive answer, as both players have solidified their places in basketball history.
Michael Jordan, known for his 6 NBA championships with the Chicago Bulls, is often praised for his scoring ability and competitiveness. On the other hand, LeBron James, a 4-time NBA champion with the Miami Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers, and the Los Angeles Lakers, is recognized for his versatility and playmaking skills on the court.
Our aim is to try and inform your decision on who is your G.O.A.T. with all the right statistics and background information. This paper will analyze various aspects of both playersâ€™ careers, including statistics, accolades, and impact on the game, in order to provide a comprehensive comparison. Ultimately, we hope to shed light on the ongoing debate and help readers make an informed decision on who they believe is the greatest basketball player of all time.
Prime Lebron James & Michael Jordan

II. Early Life and Career Beginnings: Michael Jordan
Michael Jordanâ€™s childhood begins in the town of Wilmington, North Carolina where he moved at a young age after being birthed in Brooklyn, New York. He was a stellar multi-sport athlete in the sports baseball, football, and basketball but that wasnâ€™t enough for his hometown high school of Emsley A. Laney High School. He was cut from the school varsity team in his sophomore year but soon made it back as their star athlete. After high school he played in the NCAA where he led his team to a D1 championship in only his freshman year. The following years as both a sophomore & junior he was named the NCAA college player of the year which added to his early collection of accolades. The only reason his stellar college run was cut short was because he left to join the NBA. Jordan, part of the â€˜84 draft class, was drafted 3rd overallÂ  by the Chicago Bulls.
Jordanâ€™s school picture day at his Elementary School

II. Early Life and Career Beginnings: LeBron James
Lebron Jamesâ€™s childhood was difficult to say the least. He was born to an ex-con for a father and to his mom, Gloria, when she was only 16 years old. Early in his life, he moved 6+ times, missing over a 100 days of school which showed that his parent(s) never paid attention to his education, shedding a spotlight on how he was led to sports. His first sport played was Football, which Lebron saw as his favorite sport when he was young. Finally warming up to his life, he was forced to move again. He led his hometown Akron basketball team to three state titles and was named â€œMr. Basketballâ€ in Ohio for three straight years. He decided not to go to college and went straight to the NBA where he was the number 1 pick in the 2003 NBA draft. Drafted by the Cleveland Cavaliers, his path to success got off to a rocky but strong start.
-Sports Illustrated

III. Career Achievements
Early on Jordan demonstrated his prowess by averaging 28.2 points a game winning rookie of the year (ROTY). He won his first championship in 1991 and went on to lead the Chicago Bulls to two three-peats in the 1990s. He then â€œhaving no more to proveâ€ retired in October 1993 to go play for a minor league baseball team. One season later he returned to the Bulls late in the 1994-95 season to lead them to another 3 championships in the years â€™96-98. He retired for a second time in January 1999. He went on to buy a share of the Washington Wizards and also became the president of basketball operations on the team. He returned to basketball again to join the Wizards and became the first player aged 40+ to score more than 40 PPG. Jordanâ€™s final retirement from basketball appeared in May 2003.Overall, Jordan made 6 finals appearances with a total of 6 finals wins.
Totals: Six-time NBA champion (1991-93, 1996-98); MVP (1988, â€™91, â€™92, â€™96, â€™98); 10-time All-NBA First Team (1987-93, 1996-98); All-NBA Second Team (1985); Defensive Player of the Year (1988); Nine-time All-Defensive First Team (1988-93, 1996-98); Rookie of the Year (1985); 14-time All-Star; All-Star MVP (1988, â€™96, â€™98); One of 50 Greatest Players in NBA History (â€™96); Olympic gold medalist (1984, â€™92).
Lebronâ€™s first championship came in 2012 with the Miami Heat with 27.1 PPG, followed by two more with the Heat in 2013 and the Cleveland Cavaliers in 2016. His fourth championship came with the Los Angeles Lakers in 2020, solidifying his status as one of the greatest players of all time. Additionally, his four MVP awards showcase his consistent excellence and impact on the game throughout his career. Lebron had a total of 10 Finals appearances, which he won 4 out of showcasing his capability to fight to the top even without as much support as other teams have had.
LeBron James has been selected to the All-Star game a total of 17 times, further highlighting his dominance and impact on the league. He has also won one scoring title in 2008, displaying his versatility and ability to excel in different aspects of the game. In comparison, Jordan has been selected to the All-Star game 14 times and has won 10 scoring titles, solidifying his status as one of the greatest scorers in NBA history.
IV. Off-Court Influence and Legacy â€“ Jordan

Off the court, Michael Jordanâ€™s impact on basketball culture and his global brand cannot be understated. His influence transcends the sport, as seen through his successful Jordan Brand which continues to be a powerhouse in the world of sneakers and apparel. Jordanâ€™s legacy extends far beyond his playing days, solidifying his status as a true icon in both sports and popular culture. The Jordan brandâ€™s roots actually come from his parents. Not only did Jordan not begin with Nike, he actually started the deal with Converse & Adidas. Adidas was known as Jordanâ€™s personal favorite, but when Nike offered him 250,000 â€“ more than double Adidas offered â€“ and a signature shoe, his parents urged him to take the deal. There are now 39 main flagship models with thousands of styles. Jordan serves as an inspiration no matter where he is to both NBA players and children alike. His skills and increasing influence led fans not only in the USA, but also across the entire world to hear of his prowess and in turn boost television viewership. Finally, by becoming a stake in the Charlotte Hornets, this showcased his commitment to not only playing but also coaching the new generation of basketball.

A public school founded by LeBron James in Akron, Ohio.
IV. Off-Court Influence and Legacy â€“ LeBron
Conversely, Lebron has had tremendous impact, exemplified by his nickname King James, or the Chosen One. His records are seemingly unbreakable with over 40 thousand points in the regular season, additionally, James has scored 40+ points against all 30 teams.Â  His philanthropy has taken roots in higher education, mentoring, advocacy, after-school programs, and early childhood development or learning. The LeBron James Family Foundation has raised over 100 Million for these causes. Finally, LeBron, after struggling with poverty as a child, works towards better education for those children now. As LeBron James has not retired yet, his influence is only yet to grow and the rest is history.

V. Conclusion
Overall, Lebron and Jordan have both made significant contributions to society through their philanthropic efforts and social activism. While Jordanâ€™s impact on basketball culture and global brand is undeniable, LeBron has also used his platform to create positive change in the world. Both players have left a lasting legacy that extends beyond the basketball court, solidifying their status as true icons in sports and popular culture. Finally, it all comes down to personal preference and interpretation of the facts. The choice is left up to you, the readerâ€¦
This poll has ended.
Is LeBron James or Michael Jordan the G.O.A.T.
